data.title: Review: Tegan and Sara wow crowds at Ambleside
data.meta_description: The epic rain broke to create the perfect setting for the Fun. & Tegan and Sara show at West Vancouver’s Ambleside Park on Saturday.
data.text:
The epic rain broke to create the perfect setting for the Fun. & Tegan and Sara show at West Vancouver’s Ambleside Park on Saturday.

Fun. & Tegan and Sara

With Youth and Gold & The Mowgli’s

Review: Tegan and Sara wow crowds at Ambleside Back to video

August 31 | Ambleside Park

The epic rain broke to create the perfect setting for the Fun. & Tegan and Sara show at West Vancouver’s Ambleside Park on Saturday.

The Quin twins have been carrying out a daring experiment: can a pair of singer-songwriters in their 30s become electro pop stars on their seventh album?

Article content

The transformation has involved getting a backing band, amping up the synths, and ditching the folk circuit in favour of appearances with pop power houses like Taylor Swift.

So far it seems the experiment has been a success. The crowd at Saturday evening was a mix of teens, families and edgier types. Most were probably there for headliners Fun., but they seemed more than receptive to the sister act.

Tegan and Sara’s set focused on their most recent album, Heartthrob, which has been a talisman of their new style, but also drew a few pop-inflected selections from their earlier efforts.

Though they sounded strong early on, it was clear for much of the set that Tegan was struggling. She admitted early on that she’d woken up with hives and had to take a couple of Benadryl to make it on stage.

===

VIEW MORE PHOTOS HERE, or if you're using a mobile app, tap the story image and swipe.

===

One of the duo’s strengths has always been their onstage repartee, so Tegan’s allergies became a running gag. She joked that it was the stress of being in her hometown that caused the flare up, and that she kept forgetting she wasn’t in a little jam space.

Article content

“There are about 2 million of you and you’re beautiful,” she said.

After singing Alligator from their previous album Sainthood (2009), they took a moment to praise the crowd’s dance moves, referencing the video that shows the twins dancing off their sorrows clad in a collection of knit wear.

It was clear that by the final song, the album’s single, Closer, Tegan was feeling the effects of the Benadryl. But she deserved the round of applause from the audience for making it through the set.

The sun was melting into the Burrard Inlet, the windows of West Van lighting the mountain like candles, by the time Fun. made it to stage. The American three-piece appeared in a stage corner in matching three piece suits, opening with an Queen-reminiscent Some Nights (Intro) from their most recent album of the same name. A quick change in darkness and singer Nate Ruess was back in a white sports coat over a Raptures shirt, fist-pumping the air through One Foot.

A live drummer replaced the hip-hop inspired drum beats from the album.

Ruess was a big-voiced presence, bouncing around the stage and beckoning the audience to sing along.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

“One of the biggest crowds we’ve ever played to,” he marvelled during an explosive rendition of Barlights that ended with clouds of confetti erupting into the crowd.

Some awkwardly cute stage banter ended with the band renaming the city “the Couv” and pianist Andrew Dost making the first fun-related pun made by a band member (or so claimed Jack Antonoff).

Ruess then pointed out that their stage crew is largely from Vancouver and dedicated The Gambler, a piano ballad from their first album Aim and Ignite to them and their families in the crowd.

They offered an angular cover of the Rolling Stones You Can’t Always Get You Want before following up with their ubiquitous We Are Young.

Ambleside Park, nestled as it is between mountains and ocean, made a spectacular backdrop, but it felt as though not all the kinks had been worked out of the system. With only two water stations on the whole grounds, line ups for water stretched on into the grounds. The upside of the interminable water line was that the nearby Qmunity Booth got some well-deserved attention.
